CatDescriptText: Mr. Alexander Portis, unemployed, Oakland and Miss Marlene Wilson, unemployed, Garfield, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, July 1, 1961, pg. A1 with question: "Do you think ethnic groups (like the Negro people) profit more by voting a straight party ticket, or are there better advantages for them in splitting a ticket?"  Mr. Alexander Portis' answer reads: "The Negro should not split his vote--never!  Even if he loses out, he should not do this.  Unity is all of it...."  Miss Marlene Wilson's answer reads: "It's better if he votes straight, because anything that's split is not good...."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Alexander Portis wearing light colored button down collared shirt and eyeglasses, standing in front of tree, buildings in background; Portrait of Marlene Wilson wearing dark coat with wide collar, two men and buildings in background
